cyclone.name: FRED
cyclone.current_location: about 210 miles SE of Key West, Florida

motion.direction: W (280°) – expected to bend WNW overnight

cyclone.trajectory: Moving WNW tonight, turning NW Saturday; forecast to skirt the lower Florida Keys, move northward just offshore the Florida west coast, then make landfall over the eastern Florida Panhandle/Big Bend late Sunday night or early Monday
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida Panhandle near the Big Bend/Apalachicola area

weather_observation.under_watch: None (watch begins south of Englewood, just south of the port)
weather_observation.watch_coast: South-west coast of Florida from Englewood south and east to Ocean Reef
weather_observation.warning_coast: Florida Keys west of Ocean Reef to the Dry Tortugas and Florida Bay
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Florida west coast from the Keys northward through Tampa Bay/Manatee County to the Big Bend
weather_observation.rain_fall_above_4_inch: Likely (3–6" with isolated 8" forecast for west-central FL)
weather_observation.storm_surge_above_3_feet: Possible but not certain (guidance suggests 1–3 ft, locally up to 3 ft in Tampa Bay)
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force gusts (35–45 mph) possible Saturday night through Sunday as Fred’s center passes 60–100 mi west of the port
weather_observation.storm_surge: 1–3 ft of minor coastal inundation possible in Manatee County and Tampa Bay, highest Sunday with high tide
weather_observation.rainfall: 3–6 inches of rain, locally higher, could cause urban and small-stream flooding in port vicinity
weather_observation.other_hazards: Isolated tornadoes possible beginning Saturday afternoon; rough seas and swells will hamper vessel operations through Monday
